reviewText:
Sorcerer King is a game that occupies a slightly different niche than other fantasy 4X games. In fact, if you go into this game expecting a typical 4X experience and challenge, you may well be disappointed. Yet, the differences are what made me really enjoy this game over its competitors.

The way I prefer to see SK is as an RPG with a 4X control scheme. Sure, you build cities and expand your empire, but the main focus of the game is always on your champions. You explore the world, you find and do quests, you hunt for loot to craft new equipment, and get experience for your heroes so you can handle the final boss at the end. The strategy elements are still there, but downplayed compared to the RPG elements. This is the type of game for those of us who enjoyed our hero stacks in other fantasy strategy games.

Also be warned that SK is a very text-heavy game. A lot of the quests, as well as the interactions between yourself and your various allies and enemies, are told through text boxes. The writing isn't especially deep, but is filled with humor and snark through-out. This keeps the writing interesting, even if it may seem a little jarring with the post-apocalyptic premise.

I am personally much more of an RPG gamer than a strategy one, and so it surprised me how much I ended up truly loving Sorcerer King. It definitely gets my recommendation, and I'm eager to see how the game continues to develop.

I played Fallen Enchantress for probably 200 hours.  So, of course, I figured that the negative reviews for Sorceror King were probably not going to be accurate for me.  Here it is, a week since I've bought the game and I can't even bother to try to make it through my 2nd complete game.  I'm a big fan of this company but they really missed the target with Sorceror King.

1 - Enemy armies can enter your ZOC and attack you in the same turn meaning you have no advance warning so you can try to protect yourself.

2 - I generally end up with one solid hero but he and his units have to spend half of their time Cloud Walking back to whatever territory is getting overrun by enemy units _constantly_.  I can normally get 4-6 turns away from a territory before I have to come back which significantly reduces my ability to expand.

3 - Depending on your starting spawn the game is really just, simply boring.  All you have to do is get a unit with 3+ paladins and a hero, put some good gear and +move/+initiative stuff on them and you're going to walk through anything that is put in your way.  Diplomacy is non-existent.

4 - You often find yourself in a scenario where because you walked into a Bazaar square there's no way to get out of it so you *have* to choose one of the trade options even if you don't like any of them.

At this point short of a miracle patch or DLC I don't think I'll ever play this title again.  And I have played Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes off and on for years now.

Well, first time reviewing a game on steam so i appologise in advance if its somewhat amateur.

When i first played fallen enchantress LE i was amazed at the choice and depth and sunk a ton of hours into it perfecting stacks of doom (im a min/maxer). And after all my experience i thought, this would be great if instead of fighting other factions who are similar, fight one all powerful faction and you can equip all your units individually.

And thats exactly what stardock has done with sorcerer king.

Sorcerer king is a sublte blend of RPG and 4X, but imo, more emphisis on the rpg, which is to my approval and it reminds me of the board game talisman for some reason. Its not similar in mechanics (sorcerer king is far more complex) but just the goal. Build up strong enough to fight the end game baddie, which i suppose is the goal of all rpgs. But sorcerer king sprinkles that city building element and makes it more richer for it.

The other thing about stardocks games, (and i know im going out on a limb here) but it has a style, a feel, a brand.
Something so rare with modern gaming (30+ years experience).
You know when you play a blizzard game you know its made by blizzard? Thats how i feel about stardock.

Of course im aware the two are vastly different in production but none-the-less stardock games, especially sorcerer king has love put into it.

When the developers make a game they want to play themselves, you're going to get a good game.

Faults? Yea.
Some bugs.
Some tedious parts in the game.
UI a bit cluttered.

But in all honesty, if you like this genre, these will be largely ignored by most.

Thouroughly recommended for fans of RPGs.

Slightly recommended for anyone else.

Keep doing what you're doing stardock.

Early Access Review

If you liked Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes, I absolutely recommend Sorcerer King.
If you like fantasy 4x games, I absolutely recommend Sorcerer King.
If you want to play 4x MPs... then yea, avoid Sorcerer King because it's single player only.

The 2 biggest complaints I've been hearing are:
1.  You no longer design your own units with equipment the way you did in previous FE games.
It is true, you do not.  Instead, you get generic unit types like swordsmen, spearmen, archers, riders, knights, etc.  In addition, you can form alliances with Remnant factions and get unique units that way.

However,  a crafting system has been added so you can create armour and such to equip these units!  In addition, equipment can be enhanced!
You can't change the weapon the units are equipped with, but you can give them additional armour, and add elmemental damage via rings and such.

In addition, designing units was honestly a pain in the butt in the previous games.  When you research new technologies, you got to design the unit with the upgraded equipment.  It felt tedious and time consuming.  Stardock has enhanced and streamlined the unit improvement process in SK compared to FE:LH's static unit designing.

2.  It's no longer a true 4X because of asynchronous gameplay (your goal is to kill the sorcerer king, while the SK's goal is to destroy all the shards on the map to become the eternal ruler of the world).

Well, AIs tend to be the worst part of 4x games, and generally result in these games offering very little challenge because 4x are generally too complex for an AI to do well (unless they got insane bonuses).  FE:LH suffered from this problem because the AI just wasn't very good at attacking the player or creating deadly armies (e.g. lots of high-initiative ranged attackers).

By making the gameplay asynchronous, Stardock made the AI more challenging.  The AI will spawn armies that attack the shards, which you can stop by stationing your armies to fight them off.

In other words, both changes actually improved the gameplay compared to FE:LH.


Other Improvements:
- the graphics are now much more colourful and fantasy-like.
- 6 leader types, all of which have their own technology tree and style of play based on their tech tree.
- The addition of minor factions that you can sway to your cause, who then assist you with units, technology, and/or resources

I want to start off by noting that I have not played Fallen Enchantress; but from what I have seen, while Sorcerer King is very similar, it boasts qualities that many might find more appealing.  One such quality is the fact that this game is a casual gaming experience.  (a brief pause for the stereotypical Hardcore players' gasps and shudders)  If you are a veteran 4X player hailing from the lands of Sid Meier's Civilization, Heroes of Might and Magic, or Endless Space, then you might be a little disappointed by the lack of mind bending strategies, depth of min/maxing, or precision fine tuning of global economies.  To be clear, I absolutely <3 all 3 of those games.

However, this little gem is great because of it's simplicity.  It taps into the essence of all the things that make the 4X genre great without being overly complicated (or making new users figure out what is going on in the world by using 20 different UI screens filled with charts and graphs).

Each Sovereign has an ability unique to themselves, a Champion (with starting party) that represents how they handle things on the battlefield, and a set of spellbooks.  The spellbooks determine the likelihood that spells of certain categories will appear when you reasearch.

The maps are littered with little dungeons, caves, ancient battlefields, etc; each with the purpose of delivering a little comically written quest.  When the quest is done, rewards are given, cake is eaten, and you move on your way to the next quest or enemy army.  Your Champions will level up and gain new abilities as you battle your way to the Sorcerer King's doorstep (he's a total jerk btw).  Battles are fought turn-based on a chess-like grid in a setting that reflects the area you initiated the battle.

You will encounter other races that are basically quest givers and potential allies/enemies alike.  The Sorcerer King will be trying to gain their favor as well, and some of them are sworn enemies of each other.  This means that if you ally with one, it might just be impossible for you to become friends with the other.  Having these guys on your side will provide you with periodic trade options, or some other kind of assistance in your efforts against the Sorcerer King.  While they may not provide much direct military support on their own, at least they are with you, rather than against you.

If you require your 4X to bombard you with information til your eyes bleed hashtags, then I would move along.  If you're looking for a simple 4X with a casual pace and light hearted spirit, or if you have never played a 4X game in your life and want a good entry to the genre, then look no further than Sorcerer King.

reviewText:
TL:DR - It’s a good game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys games of this genre.  Read the rest of this review for more detail.

I’ll start this review off by saying that I wasn’t a huge fan of Fallen Enchantress or Elemental: War on Magic games.  I found each of them would degenerate into a grind once the initial exploration phase was done with.

However Sorcerer King dodges this bullet and maintains it’s pace and interest throughout.  This is basically because it’s not trying to be a fantasy TBS 4X game, it’s more a hybrid between an RPG and a TBS 4X.  I’ll sum my thoughts up with a series of bullet points below:

Pros:
+  Streamlined 4X elements – fewer cities, more focus on a few groups of units.  Although this will probably deter people who are expecting a pure 4X game.
+  RPG/Quests – they’re all basically multi-choice quests that will grant certain rewards based on your decisions.  However they’re well written and grant points associated with your playstyle (for example +1 courage for attacking a group of bandits rather than running from them).  These in turn (as you rack them up) will trigger events as the game progresses.
+  Quick, tactical combat – nothing revolutionary but the battles are quick, and straightforward.  The available tactics are limited and generally revolve around clever use of skills and initiative.  They’re much better than in the FE and E:WoM games which had your troops taking 2 or 3 turns running across the battlefield before they’d even be able to enter combat.
+  The doomsday counter and interactions with the Sorcerer King adds flavour and an element of urgency.  It really does feel like you skulking around in the shadows in the first part of the game.

Cons
-  The AI isn’t fantastic.  I often had enemies run through burning tiles in tactical battles, resulting in them dying when they could have just gone around it.  Also while fighting the ice lieutenant it repeated targeted one of my units that was immune to cold based attacks, leaving my other units to slowly whittle away his health.  Making the combat much, much easier than it should have been.
-  As the Sorcerer King raises the threat that he perceives you to be you’ll find that he will send more and more troops against you.  This is fine but they just appear as monster lairs which your borders, which seems a bit of a cheat to me.
-  Replayability isn’t fantastic.  I’ve completed the game and all I can do now is more of the same.  The different Sovereigns do make a small amount of difference to how you play but fundamentally the game will largely play out the same regardless.  More winning conditions or different races would make the game much more replayable.

Other/General
*  Graphics are clean and do the job.  It’s a shame that changing a characters weapons/armour doesn’t show on the unit but it’s not a big deal.
*  The music does a good job of reflecting the type of game this is.  Sound is fine.
*  I’ve not experienced any bugs while playing
*  The crafting mechanic can become a little laborious later on but it’s fun finding and trying out new recipes
*  The army design mechanic that was in the previous titles has been removed which may irritate a few people.

Anyway this has become a bit of wall of text so I’ll leave it there and add a TL:DR section at the top.

reviewText:
Sorcerer King is the first game I've played since Master of Magic to capture its, uh, magic. There are differences, to be sure, but I feel the additions, like a material-based crafting system for items, much more than the absent features, like more playable races.

Sorcerer King is inspired by MoM, but it's not trying to clone it (*cough* Worlds of Magic *cough*). There are minor factions you can ally with or declare war on, but you always have one ultimate opponent: the Sorcerer King. This neatly solves the problem in MoM of needing to wipe out each opponent in turn: once you defeat the SK, the game is won. There is also a Spell of Mastery–like win condition for at least some of the sovereigns.

There are still some bugs in 1.0, but nothing too horrible. It only crashed on me about three times in 45 hours of gameplay, which isn't bad for this type of game.

I hope SK continues to improve; I've already seen talk of adding additional races, which would be a nice touch if done well.

Not so much sleep before work tonight...
I quickly knew that I like this game, because it feels like an improved Fallen Enchantress.

I like how the plot makes for a natural thrill in the game - as time passes and your kingdom grows, you are running out of time and the Sorcerer King is growing impatient with you. It's like watching a movie in which rebels will team up to fight a tyran.
Not only do you have to stop the Sorcerer's ongoing plans while he is watching you, but your choices in all kinds of random events will hasten or slow the Sorcerer's progress. You actually might have to think twice about your choices: Will you be greedy, get instant results and hasten the doom clock? Or will you be kind, let go of treasures and win time?

Map resources feel very valuable as they are not plentiful, but this might change as the game development continues.

Spells and items are very much like in Fallen Enchantress, except you now have random chances to research less common spells. There is no tech tree, but you don't really notice.

Item shops have been replaced by a crafting system, which really feels a ton better than the shops.
In order to craft an item you need both the teachings for that item and the crafting materials - which are random drops.
You can't just hoard whatever items you want, regardless of how rich you are. You need luck, patience and planning.
That reminds me: There is no gold or such all-round currency here! It's an improvement, as there is no longer any resource that can be hoarded and used to buy everything and anything.

Units cannot be customized like in Fallen Enchantress. BUT, trained units may now equip most items just like your heroes! As such, the difference between heroes and units has been reduced. Units cannot learn new skills and they cannot equip weapon items, but they are otherwise pretty much like heroes.

As of now what I miss the most is more variety of spells, buildings and items, and customizing when creating a game.
I'm sure all of these will come before the game is released - plus the possibility of creating your own!

Its just fun

I don't play a lot of RPGs and only played a little of Legendary Heroes and Fall Enchantress. This game while utilizing the same engine and universe as those previous titles feels a lot different from those games which is an  RPG of tactical combat with some civilization elements.

You start the game as a soveriegn which each has a very different set of skills and different beginning spells. You can pick one of the 6 or customize your sovereign's starting hero and spellbooks which give you access to spells of a certain type (wrath is damage, summon is summon creatures). You'll start with a single city and expand from there going on quests fighting monsters and bandits and eventually the sorcerer king himself before he can cast a spell which is measured in the dooms day counter.

You'll want to watch the dev streams on stardock's youtube channel to get a clearer idea of how the game works but that's it in a nutshell. The things that still need work are some minor bugs (there's the occassional having to click turn button twice, missing icons for tile yields and odd spell effects) but nothing to break the game and these have been improved and fixed over time. There's also some unit abilities that need more clearer definition in what they do and some AI improvements to make the other minor factions more aggressive.

One of the chief concerns I had playing this game when I first started in the beta was this going to have much replay value after the first few games. Suffice I was surprised to find myself keeping coming back to it and looking forward to each game and I realized the main reason: It's fun.

The game's not overally complicated with research, and deep-seeded strategy, though there is some. It's game of you leading a group of units leveling your hero, making choices that have an impact on the game and killing a bunch of monsters and enemies.  The quests are fun to read, you can ally yourself with fire and elemantal creatures that each their own personality and abilities. You'll get some awesome units over the course of the game, find cool loot and find some great comboes (though a few are a bit much even though I love Varda the Slayer's combo of abilities)

Since playing the Beta the game has come a long way in everything from content, features and units. reviewText:
Sorcerer King is a great game, i'm not particularly into 4X but this one has a fairly easy gateway of entry. Considering it's brand new and not a high price, it's a good one to pick up and sink some hours into. The learning curve is extremely minimal, only taking between 60-90 minutes to grasp the basic mechanics, and then you're quickly onto more advanced strategies and higher levels of aggression. I never found the AI to be devastating however, even on insane difficulties. Sure it would endlessly harass my shards/kingdoms - being a nusance as opposed to a legitimate threat, but it would  never stress me or lure me out.

The AI often opts to win by default, by which I mean it throws medium forces at your main force to cause attrition (this doesn't affect the AI because, of course, it has infinite resources and unit production). This also has the effect of causing the 'doom timer' to tick by as you're paralyzed by endless harrying. Sure I guess it's a legitimate battle tactic, but if quickly gets tiresome; it's not intelligence, it's simply an abuse of resource advantage.

This is more of a game that attempts to hook you in and then by your own desire you explore the various leader characters and their stats/spells (increasing play time). They do often provide an interesting twist and the skirmish maps were varied enough in scope/scale/challenges/uniqueness that I gave most of them a full playthrough prior to this review.

I haven't experiened any significant bugs or crashes aside from one particular frustrating element. When casting hypnosis on specific enemy units (wargs especially) the game would often freeze up on the next manual battle; causing a soft crash. The only cure was to either disband the unit or place them in a keep as stalwart defenders. It's troublesome because hypnosis costs resources and those converted units typically have a good hit point to damage ratio, making them worthwhile units to steal from the enemy. On higher difficulties this ability can really turn the battle and keep things interesting, it's just a shame it causes so much grief (at time of review).

That singular issue  aside however, I have had no other crashes or even bugs in the game; it's surprisingly robust. Your experience may vary (the other reviews on here do seem to have had trouble), but frankly I would assume it to be a problem with your system before the game's.

It's a good 7.5/10. It's fairly inexpensive, can create some fun adventures (I hypnotised Kevin the Dragon and used his mega Charizard flame burst to literally burn my way to the enemies citadel), and has a good sense of humour in the writing and gameplay. Pick it up if you get a chance.

reviewText:
I am new to strategy games but this game has been very enjoyable since I bought it.  I don't know if it was worth the $40 I paid for it but if I get to 100 hours then I think it will be worth it.  Here are some of the reasons why I like this game...

1.  The game is relatively easy to pick up.  It took me a few restarts but once I got how the progression worked through the game, I started to enjoy it a lot.  Again I am new to this genre so thats just me learning.
2.  The sovereigns make how you play so much different.  If  you pick the commander sovereign, he makes your army more powerful through talents tthat increase their stats when you make them in your cities, and by the number of army slots you can have in each army.  The guardian sovereign makes it to where your outposts can really control the map by making their zone of control larger...much larger.  The tinkerer allows you to craft a whole lot of different items rather quickly, allows more enchant slots on each item, and allows for certain unique recipes.  An example of this is the arrows you can make that go into accessory slots for archers.  Making these and fully enchanting them can makes things a bit too easy though I have found out, especially if you picked the ranger hero.
3.  The map is full of plenty of things to explore.  The campaign map is rather large and uncovering it all will take quite a long time.
4.  The graphics on everything seem to be really smooth and the sound effects are on point.

Along with the good are the bad.  Here are a few examples of them...
1.  The AI is rather dull in this game.  I am only playing on the default difficulty setting since im new to this type of game, but I find the map easy to controll for the most part because the sorcerer kings army is not that bright.  They don't attack often enough.
2.  There is no way to save an army composition.  If you move one of your armies into a city, you have to drag each unit 1 by 1 out of the city and reform the army.  This is a bit annoying.
3.  The doomsday counter seems too easy to control.  I really feel no sense of urgency because I can keep the doomsday counter down to 0 most of the time.  I think the amount of quests that reduce this counter should be reduced.
4.  Very little difference in army options no matter what sovereign you play.  Certain sovereigns have special units you can unlock through their talent tree but unit options seems too limited at the moment.  The mages are useless, there's no healer unless you go with the cleric sovereign (unless i'm mistaken), the archers are crap unless you have the ranger hero or you went the tinkerer sovereign.
5.  There's a bug that effects your spells.  I've noticed that if you messed up and want to reload one of the autosaves, the last spell that you learned will show back in your learning queue.  This is really annoying, especially in the beginning part of the game.

There are good and bad points to the game but I find it overall enjoyable.  I really don't have room to compare this game to others because I'm new to this type of game so I'm sorry for that.  I hope this helps some people decide.  I will be updating this review as I go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sorcerer King is still in early access but already adds some interesting mechanics to traditional fantasy 4X games in the form of asymmetrical gameplay. You are trying to stop an already advanced and strong AI empire from destroying magical shards placed around the map to end the game. The games looks are improved over Fallen Enchantress and Legendary Heroes while also feeling further along in development (and more fun to play) than Stardock's other beta game Galactic Civilizations III at this point in time.

The big thing currently missing is the minor factions/diplomacy system which is expected in the next couple of weeks. Apart from that along with a lack of race and map customization (which are currently locked), the game is a lot of fun to play and runs well with minimal bugs. Sorcerer King is one to keep an eye on if you are looking for a few twists in what is otherwise a fairly traditional but well done fantasy 4X game.

Cons:
- No multiplayer. Even though the game is turn-based.
- Not much replayibility as there is only one campaign and one map. Each time, the map is randomized, but the factions/mainquest spots are unchanged.
- AI gets dumb at some points. Needs some work.
- Sounds go mute sometimes, for very short periods.
- Sense of humour might be too much for some people who are looking for a serious story.

reviewText:
I enjoyed Sorcerer King.  Having been a fan of Galactic Civilizations 2, Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes, and to a lesser extent Galactic Civilizations 3, it seemed like a no brainer to try Stardock's latest entry in the Elemental series, especially when Steam had it on sale for less than $12.  I like it and recommend it, with some caveats.  Fans of previous elemental games who are expecting the full 4X experience that Legendary Heroes has will be a bit disappointed.  Sorcerer King feels more like a subgenre spinoff of Legendary Heroes than a true sequel.  While there is exploration, expansion, exploitation of resources, and extermination of foes, all of these things are dialed back in favor of the game's main objective which is to defeat the sorcerer king.  Instead of negotiating trade agreements with other kingdoms, you are now simply attempting to gain their favor so that they will aid you against the Sorcerer King (though the aid really seems to be in name only... I never witnessed any of my allies sending troops to fend off the Sorcerer King's armies).  Alternatively, you can choose to go to war with them and wipe them out, or if they become the Sorcerer King's thralls they will permanently declare war against you.  Also, let's talk about the Doomsday Clock.  It's actually not as bad as it sounds.  Yes, the Sorcerer King does keep building up the timer to doomsday, and when the game first starts and the timer rises it seems pretty hopeless.  Then as you gain power, you find ways to turn back the timer so it's really kind of a non issue.  By the endgame I had completely turned the timer back to zero.

In addition to the trimmed down diplomacy options, the game is also missing one of the best features of previous Elemental games, which is the dragons!  Sure, they were incredibly overpowered, but who didn't love taking over a dragon cave and growing their very own nuclear option that was sure to turn the tide of almost any battle?  Also instead of the many titans that showed up in Legendary Heroes, this game has only two which must be defeated for one of the possible paths to victory.

So overall, I enjoyed Sorcerer King though not as much as Legendary Heroes.  For replay value, Legendary Heroes has so much more to do.  However if you enjoy the Elemental series, or Stardock games in general, it's worth picking up and trying, especially if you find it on sale.

I was on the fence for this review. I'm making it positive because I do enjoy the game. The reason I was on the fence is that I think that many will not like it. I love FE Legendary Heroes, this seems dumbed down in many ways from that and that's what most probably won't enjoy. The options here are far less in every way, less leader choices, units, spells, buildings have no options, maps, map options like many resources or few are not there either.

Outposts are really cool but the AI needs to use them too and they need to be able to be destroyed somehow even if not easily, a high mana spell or something. Maybe having them destructable could be an option in your world options when creating a game, just a thought. The leaders, few that they are do play very different and if played to their strengths they are all equally capable, The balance is very impressive as most games there will be one leader choice that is far stronger than the rest, in this game each time you try a new leader they seem great.

Heroes and units leveling endlessly is cool too, it'd be nice to see non hero units get a skill choice on occassion even if it was only every 10 levels or so and even if it was a skill that was passive chose greater attack against beast or spell caster, or anything.

All of that said I do enjoy the game and I'm happy that I bought it, it's a different game that Fallen Enchantress LH so of course everything wouldn't be the same. They say that they plan to add many more things so time will tell. There's a few bugs, I read of some and I've only found one myself, some type of graphical thing where you start getting a black screen when other leaders talk to you, you can still see the text and saving/restarting makes it go away for a few hours.

Bottom line, it's worth trying, if you like it then you can also try Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes and you'll probably enjoy it too. Sorry if I was all over the place, there's a ton that I really like about this game and several things that I don't ;)

reviewText:
I got the game for $30 during launch week because Stardock is awesome to their returning customers and sent out a 25% off coupon, but I'd reccomend the game at $40 too. I think it's important to understand that this is a different type of game than Fallen Enchantress/Legendary Heroes. That was more of a traditional 4X while this launches you into an a-symetric war story.

Pros -
1) Good mechanics, deep enough to provide an initial challenge, but not a frustrating learning curve
2) Good lore/story built into play - the player makes choices that matter really frequently
3) Smooth but not awe inspiring graphics (its a 4X game, presumably this is what they're going for)
4) Crafting - has gotten mixed responses with some people saying it's not powerful enough, I find it to be well balanced in terms of time spent crafting to advantage it gives in battle

Cons -
1) Replayability - On the plus side I played at least a half dozen games on different map sizes and difficulty levels, both of which give a different experience to the game, however:
i) Unfortunately after a couple play throughs you realize that there is an optimal way to build every city and there is no queue, so that means going back to each city every time you build something to figure out where you are in that city's build order (annoying)
ii) Limited number of units and balance between them in the late game makes strategic decisions at the end of the game much easier than at the begining and needs to be developed more, such as balance between mounted units (most powerful) and magical units (severly under powered)
2) Stats and tooltips - Some states just aren't explained anywhere, like Spell Mastery, which seems like it could be important, but I still have no idea after 50 hours

Anyone still reading has seen that despite a couple of issues I have with the game (as of version 1.0), I still reccomended it. Expect to get 40-80 hours of enjoyment out of the game and then have basically played out the various senarios running into replayabilty walls... if 40-80 hours of entertainment is worth $40 then by all means go for it because I haven't regretted any of the time I spent playing.

reviewText:
A game that combines strategy and RPG mechanics all in one package.  Using the same formula as the venerable Lords of Magic and its predecessor Fallen Enchantress, Sorcerer King incrementally improves the formula and manages to build an interesting fantasy setting while it's at it.  With tongue-in-cheek mini-quests that spice up the exploration, as well as a doomsday timer that doesn't let the player simply turtle and assemble an overwhelming army, Sorcerer King manages to maintain a pacing that sometimes eludes long campaign-based strategy games with one big map to explore.  Like the better 4x games, this is a game that grabs you and keeps prodding you to keep going.  I'm 20 hours into the campaign and I've only explored half the map, so we're looking at 40-50 hours for one playthrough.

Versus Fallen Enchantress, the campaign feels a little more story-driven than the default map of Fallen Enchantress, but much more open-ended than that game's campaign.  I like the balance they struck with the quest system and dialogue options, giving the world flavor without hemming the player in.  I do kind of miss the linear story, being a fan of RPGs, but this works too.

The battle is more refined than Fallen Enchantress.  High-level warriors were essentially invincible in FE and could solo just about anything with life drain equipment (or was it Lords of Magic?).  In Sorcerer King even a high-level warrior with really strong defense can get overwhelmed by crowds of low-level enemies due to stacking flanking bonuses.  This of course works both ways.

The scenario encourages rapid exploration to grab crystal fragments, while punishing reckless settlement by drawing increasing attention from your foes, who will send increasingly powerful armies to squish you with each new city.  Building a ton of new settlements all at once early in the game will likely draw swift retaliation and a premature end, forcing the player to strike a balance between beating the doomsday timer and expanding before having the means to deal with the armies of your main foe.

In short, if you're a fan of 4X games, especially the fantasy genre, then you should pick this up.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game very much.  Once I got the hang of the mechanics, I found myself playing for hours.  The game shares features from games like Civilization and Heroes of Might & Magic.  It's interesting to start in a game where the evil sorcerer has already won and taken over the land.  At the top of the screen, there's a doomsday meter that fills up every now and then and if you let it fill completely, you lose.  However, in the beginning the Sorcerer King doesn't find you a threat.  Not only does his forces ignore you unless you attack them first (in which case, the game will warn you that you're about to go to war with the Sorcerer King), but you have many opportunities to accept his help.  Sometimes he'll give you supplies, warriors, or magic in return for filling the doomsday bar a bit further.  You can also reduce the meter by completing quests honorably and using an expensive spell that also lowers the doomsday bar.  There's even a hero you can play as who feeds off of the doomsday meter, earning powerful spells and stats the closer to doomsday you are.

The dialogue is light hearted and funny.  Even some descriptions of units add a little bit of humor.  The pioneer unit, for example, explains that it is good at creating outposts, good at making settlements, and good at dying if no other units are around to protect it. The mana you gain can be used to cast spells during battle, give buffs to your cities, and even go as far as changing the landscape of the map.  In one such case, I used a spell to destroy a mountain instead of going completely around it.  On top of getting a shortcut to my destination, I also gained some crafting supplies from the rubble.
With unique features, such as the doomsday counter, along with  funny dialogue, many spells,  and 9 races/heroes to choose from, Sorcerer King kept me entertained for hours on end.   There wasn't anything with the game that I didn't like.  I just have a few small things I'd like changed/added to the game. I've been playing for 15 hours so far, and haven't come across any glitches.  I recommend this game to anyone who loves fantasy elements with a sense of humor.

reviewText:
After finally beating this on hard I can review. TL;DR The game is worth to buy. Definitely, way better than many other games. It plays like Civ on the tactical map with the battle system of Heroes of Might and Magic, systems tried and greatly enjoyable.

What sets it apart is the interesting storyline, the *massive* campaign map(I have not delved on the skirmish maps yet and the tons of quests that can happen around it. Sadly the campaign with its masiveness starts you on the same place each time, but I know Skirmish Maps have randomized starting positions. Gameplay wise I cannot comment on too much without spoiling the surprise. I personally found the ability to summon units ridiculously powerful on the late game since I could explore the map with pioneers and each time they were attacked I could bring in an army of elementals in the battle map to win the fight. But I focused all my resources on being able to do that and it was very rewarding.

All in all the game encourages you to focus on one particular tactic and if you do that you can beat the hardest challenges. Again the campaign map is humongous and it took me ~20 hours to beat it on hard difficulty and I still had explored 60% of it.

As a negative side, I can say that the sound bugs up sometimes, and some improvements could be done on occasions where the AI takes your own units for a spin(such as on instant attack abilities or berserk-like abilities). There is an option for realistic combat animations where the units fights between tiles but on low res monitors this can make the units disappear.

There are cases where the animations and the otherwise smooth audio makes this a 3/5 in comparison to the best games out there, but I would give it a personal 4/5 because of the numerous neutral units you can recruit and the incredible variety this gives to your army. Almost every event allows you to recruit moppey bandits, failed barbers and bad shopkeepers and if you take care of them soon you have legendary heroes in your army. On my campaign the Sorcerer King fell to my army of heroes, including 2 Crazed Libraries and a Poor Yeti Philosopher that I had trained to perfection.

If you enjoy games like Civ and HMM you will definitely love this I can guarantee that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WOW!

I have just finished playing my first successful playthrough of Sorcer King by stardock. I had tried two previous times, choosing as I usually do to start learning games on a difficult setting to find out where the learning curve really is. I really enjoyed fallen enchantress and considered it the spiritual successor to master of magic from way back when.

In this latest 4x fantasy kingdom builder I found alot of giddy reminders of old play dynamics amid gaming concepts established in other gaming genres. Now rather than resources being narrowed down to a few basic commodities, much of the game is set around exploration and interaction with the environment.characters, crafting ingredients, and recipes are all hidden about the map and availbile as quest rewards, giving a new emphasis to getting out onto the map and securing as much 'low hanging fruit' as possible.

The pace of the game is controlled by the doomsday counter which I found to matter more when in a defensive posture then when out raiding on the map and being heroic. The mechanic of suffering penalties or earning rewards forcertain play styles made strategic use of certain spells a consideration.

While there were a number of bugs I encountered with city production, the bigger hassle I experinced was in enduring the game's sense of humor. Most of the game establishes this feeling of impending doom and having to make long term strategic descions in order to advance, the humor seemed to me quite silly and over the top. Setting aside this glaring dichotmy, this is one of the best strategic game experinces I have had in a long long time.

Been playing this for a while, it's been improving steadily since the original beta.   This is not a traditional 4X.  It's not supposed to play like a traditional 4X.  In some ways, I'd say this is more like a roguelike or RPG that uses 4X conventions.

The idea is to build your stack of doom/companions of doom, then take on the Big Bad (Sorcerer King).  It's a really neat concept, and the execution is getting there.   Now that it's out of beta, I can say that this as of right now, is my personal game of the year.

This game has a wide variety of challenges, and you can customize it to be a cakewalk, or make it really hard (setting Doomsday to fast really forces aggression and makes it much harder).   There's also a neat number of abilities- and the process of exploring, levelling, and fighting is fun.

Stardock has a lot of experience doing Early Access, having done it themselves before Steam was even created (the original GalCiv had EA)- so it's safe to assume they will deliver on the product.

For anyone who might remember, Stardock came out with a game called Elemental: War of Magic.  At launch, the game was unplayable.  So much so that the lead dev ended up giving everyone who purchased the game around launch the first 2 DLC's for free.  This was to ease the sheer amount of backlash the company received over the broken game.  After actually listening to the community and hiring some key devs, Fallen Enchantress came out (first DLC) and all was forgiven.  Then, Legendary Heroes came out and made the game even better.  However, now we have the Sorcerer King, an offshoot from the Elemental games... and Stardock apparently didn't learn their lessons with Elemental: War of Magic.

Sorcerer King is a broken mess.  Much of the game is riddled with bugs, some completely game-breaking.  There was a livestream that I watched where a guy sacrificed a thug to gain an extra spell cast.  However, despite the thug being off the map, the thug still had a turn and could be moved and sacrificed over and over again.  That was the start of the snowballing of bugs that riddled his game.  The thug was still alive on the tactical map.  However, whatever army he was in seemed to double itself.  The player moved his army to a spot to take out a Sorcerer King's attacking army.  However, on the next turn, he found that the army he moved had disappeared and the real army was in his city.  He lost that crystal.

Then, there was the issue of complete brokeness of his conversion spell he attained through gaining enough Bravery.  He could have almost every mob that didn't have a high enough spell resist, to become his permanent unit.  He even successfully used it on drakes.  What made it even more broken was that the units that he converted didn't use up any of his Logistics like all the units that he trained would use.

I have experienced game-breaking bugs such as trying to level up a city only to have the screen unexplicably move over to an army and I could not exit out.

This game, in its current form is a broken mess.  Unless things are fixed, I would not recommend anyone buy it at all.

reviewText: Sorcerer King is novel and remarkably well designed for a Stardock game. There's a tight focus on what spells, units, and buildings exist and they all serve a specific purpose. Units are also designed to fill a niche, with interesting synergies. The design is that are secretly building up your forces to defeat a much more powerful sorcerer king. In order to build up your forces you create secret alliances and level up your units by crafting items and defeating random monsters. There are also 'goodie huts' that allow you to make designs that follow certain aligments. While the gameplay mechanics work great, I think the overall design is kind of boring and not worth more than one play though. Part of what makes a 4x fun is the continual struggle to outpace your opponents. Here, there are no equivalent opponents. You just craft and level up, your heroes are immortal, and nothing attacks you until the end game.\n\nI would recommend the game because the core gameplay mechnics are so wel done its worth looking at. However, there is no real challenge; it amounts to a level grind followed by a final boss battle. Furthermore, the game is very buggy. It will crash every 30 minutes or so, and just bug out where you cannot move or control particular units every few turns.

reviewText:
Base Line Up Front - Stay away from this title

Very upsetting step-back in the Elemental series. Would have been acceptable as their first title.

They gutted concepts entirely that made the series stand out (albiet they had issues with some of those concepts but instead of improving they just removed them)

And when you streamline a 4x  game, it makes matches painfully long. And I really shouldn't use the term streamline because that might give you the impression of efficiency. Diluted, simple and colorless would better describe it.

Examples of things I found most off-putting:

-Can't be any faction other than the Kingdom of Altar
-Heavily reduced unit customization
-Game ending bug of reaching top sovereign level and finding no way to progress
-Challenge curve went from normal to being an unstoppable steamroller finding 1 out of 20 fights worth being involved in directly
-Limited building options
-No more research choices, just a random set of spells to pick
-Couldn't understand why some weapons I could equip on units, while others (most others) only for certain champions. (can't express how frustrating it was to have many armies fully equipped with armor/accessories and NO weapons)
-general feeling that devs wanted to use the bare-minimum content from previous titles to get another title out ASAP for larger profit margins (admittedly I have no real evidence to support this)
-got it on sale and still feel shorted
-when interacting with the AI factions or questing, your character has the attitude of a quirky teenager the entire time. Imagine being a fearless death-magic casting tyrant who talks like a millenial half-witted hipster.

Frankly I've nothing nice to say about it.

All in all, this may be the last nail in the coffin for the series for me. I will be hard pressed to invest in anything the devs push out in the future.

reviewText:
What are my personal impressions about this game?
Well first of all i was a bit sceptical at first due to the fact that i wasn't really impressed by what was shown during the beta.
However having played (still playing tbh) it some time after release and having bought it at a nice -55% discount i have to honestly say that i am really liking and enjoying this game (even more so than FE:LH) but as i already said, that's just my personal opinion.
What do and don't i like? Well the coloring has been really nicely done and that's why i'm currently liking it way better than FE:LH due to the fact that i had a difficult time knowing what the exact tiles where to move to etc. This time everything is much better visible so i don't mess up my actions anymore. The story is nice and interesing the way you have to keep track of the Doom counter (it does require you to be a do gooder, but that's only during the campaign part basically, unless you want to make things harder?) so it's in your best interests to not follow into your Dark Sovereighn's footsteps all too often.
The 'hero controlled' armies can grow in size pretty quickly so that's also a good thing if you like myself like to smash larger foes or armies with much more ease. The map isn't that diverse (but still appealing enough) yet that could have been done a whole lot better impo, but who knows what future dlc installments might hold?
The look of the game in gereral, units, items, etc has been greatly improved with this game so people who like some eye candy will surely like what they see delivered within this game.
The pace can sometimes slow itself down a bit, and pop-ups can be a bit too frequent/annoying at times but i guess that's what you get from conspiring/siding against one's own 'Evil' Lordship..
There are currently (only) 6 major heroes to start out with, and while that not being much, they offer quite different and unique ways of playing the game to keep things fun and interesting.
Spells, development, building ect has pretty much been left untouched here so for those who're already familiar with the Elemental franchise will also be please having that seen returned as well.
There's much to say but i'll not spoil everything for you guys, but i will say this much..
Give this game a chance (get it with a nice discount) and judge for yourself if this game is to your liking or not?
For me personally it is, and i think that's what matters most in the end and not always what others have to say about it..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not buy this game in its current state.  It feels not like a beta, but a demo.  Demos should be free.

Right now there is no semblance of balance between the player and the AI, on any difficulty setting.  Enemies scale in power sharply and for no reason, and no amount of crafting or leveling ever brings your units up to par fast enough.  If you have enough patience with Cheat Engine you can edit values during the game to achieve some level of parity and test out the combat mechanics, but if you don't do that it's very one-sided.

The basic accuracy of units is very, very low.  Therefore, most units miss constantly.  Allied units built at the base are garbage.

There is potential here, but this game is nowhere near complete.  If you liked War of Magic you might like this one, unfortunately this is NOT a beta but an alpha/demo at this point.

The gaming industry currently has a huge problem with companies making money off of unfinished products and it's encouraging a very low standard of game quality.  Paying full price for alpha-level demo's is one reason why they get away with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has come a long way and is now more or less release-ready (and it will be out of early access next week, I believe).

If you loved prior games from the Fallen Enchantress series, then you'll love this game. It's a really good fanasy 4x game with RPG elements for your heroes and armies. Nonetheless, the game engine continues to stutter and pause unexpectedly on larger maps, even with a 64 bit operating system, 16 gigs of RAM, a GTX 970, and the fastest i5 processor currently on the market. But, the stutters and pauses aren't as bad as in previous games.

Graphics are passable but not great. It's like a civilization game: you don't play it for the graphics. You play it for the gameplay.

And the gameplay has a lot of interesting features, a few of which I've never seen in a 4x game before. The most notable feature is the doomsday counter. You see, the bad guy (the Sorceror King) has already won. You were one of his generals who is now in charge of a city. You learn he is planning a doomsday spell to end the world, so you decide to revolt. But, he doesn't know you're revolting yet. This makes things VERY interesting because:

1) If you reveal that you're revolting from him before you're strong enough (by your diplomatic interactions with him, by attacking his forces, or by other interactions) then he'll send his forces against you and wipe you out, and

2) If you don't defeat him by the time the Doomsday counter is full, then the world is destroyed and you lose.

So #1 forces you to be stealthy, in a way, and #2 forces you to be aggressive. But being too aggressive too early means you'll fail at #1 and he'll wipe you out. In other words, you have to walk a fine line and use REAL STRATEGIC THINKING when planning things out.

Also, you can accept help from the Sorceror King to bolster your forces (he believes you're still on his side after all, at least initially), but doing so advances the doomsday counter.

Guys, I can't tell you how absolutely GENIUS and BRILLIANT this gameplay mechanic is! You have to walk a fine line or all is lost. This is the BEST innovation in 4x gaming since the original Civilization game came out, in my humble but expert opinion!

You can find great gear by completing quests or defeating powerful enemies, but often the best gear is made by crafting - after you get the blueprint and crafting components by, you guessed it: completing quests, defeating powerful enemies, and opening chests spread randomly over the map (which usually only contain crafting components, not actual treasure.)

There's also a ton of spells to research, that your sovereign casts, and combat is turn-based. So you get a fantasy Civ game with RPG elements, with a combat system a bit like the Heroes of Might & Magic or games of that ilk.

So, all in all it's a great game with a few new and interesting ideas that make gameplay interesting and unique enough to make this game stand out from the crowd. It's easily Stardock's best 4x fantasy strategy game yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of writing, the game just got a balance pass, and everything is kicking into high gear!

Sorcerer King is an asymmetric 4X, which basically means the enemy (the Sorcerer King) has already won, and you play a minor faction secretly (or openly) building up your forces and biding your time to one day stop the Sorcerer King from casting the Spell of Making and becoming a god and ending the game for you. Along the way, there are other minor factions who may choose to ally with you, or (the rogues!) with the Sorcerer King.

Where the game shines is in the many interlinking systems that make up the customization and gameplay. There's the crafting system, which allows you to create armor, weapons, scrolls, potions etc. from found loot, and equip them to your units, giving a really good way to 'build up' your forces, and in a really organic way. There's the Shards system, which calls for strategic planning of where to place your cities and outposts in order to harvest all-important Shards which generate Magic, which is split into your Skill, Lore, or Mana (basically ruler abilities, research points, and currency.)

Skill allows you to choose abilities in your Sovereign skill tree (ruler abilities), which vary according to your choice of Sovereign, and which grow alongside individual Champion trees for each of your Champions (hero units.) Lore (research points) can be used to choose one spell out of a randomized short list of available spells, which keeps each choice fresh and makes every choice important. Mana is your currency for casting these spells, and for other things like unit abilities and fast-buying city improvements.

Cities grow organically, according to their Food production, and as they level, you choose the next tile to expand into, depending on the Labor, Food, or Essence of that tile. Labor determines how fast your improvements and units build, while Essence determines how many City Enchantments you can cast on it.

All in all, the game is, even in this beta stage, a wonderful amalgamation and interlinking of all these systems. Every choice you make feels important, because it is important, because it affects some other thing that will affect some other thing in the game. At the end of the day, you're not simply making optimizations or doing management, but making some small degree of impact upon your final victory or defeat through each individual choice in all the different systems and mechanisms that come together to form the game.

Tactical combat (yes! tactical combat!) is square-grid based, and is snappy and to the point. Here too, choices matter, in tactical decisions such as movement, placement, ability usage, Sovereign spell casts, etc. Death for each unit feels final, as there aren't many ways to bring them back, and somehow you end up caring for each unit. Whether this be through their accumulated XP and levels, the equipment you put on them, or just because each unit plays an important part in every battle, or because a lot of them come with a cool backstory (like horse thieves that you forcefully reform into solders) or because you can name them silly names like Ben or Bill, it all really feels great, and you start to care for your men (though they're not always 'men.')

Exploration on the beautifully-drawn map is a joy. The landscape is lush and filled with treasure chests of resources for crafting, lairs of monsters for you to do heroic (or unheroic things) and gain XP and sweet loot, terrain of differing kinds, and outposts and cities of the other factions and the Sorcerer King. As you explore, you are faced with choices at each lair that gains you points in Compassion, Cowardice, Fame, Intimidation, and other personal qualities, that go on to have game effects according to each quality that you become strong in. The stories are entertaining, and multitudinous enough to not feel too repetitive, and each choice results in differing results with both combat and non-combat consequences.

The only thing the game is missing IMHO right now is more playable races, but this can be fixed in future expansions or DLCs if the developers will it. The devs are friendly too and responsive to forum posts, and run a weekly (or thereabout) dev stream on Twitch where you can chat to them directly.

I'm not new to Stardock's style, and have played plenty of other 4X's in different genres (both sci-fi and fantasy), but Sorcerer King is a definite gem with lots and lots of potential. Support this awesome product to see it grow with more expansions!

Definite thumbs up, YES, YES, YES I recommend this game.

Edit: Forum peoples are concerned about the Sorcerer King countdown, which is the countdown to the god-becoming spell that the Sorcerer King will cast. But there are actions and events in the game that slow the countdown or even set it back, so the countdown has elements of a push-and-pull between you and the Sorcerer King, and is not entirely an unstoppable timer. The countdown can also be set in the options to be slow.

You may or may not have a preference for the countdown, but it's not as bad as it sounds (this coming from someone who also had the same understandable knee-jerk reaction against a 'time limit'). But it adds a good amount of urgency to your actions without becoming unbearable, and is a great push towards achieving your goal in the game.

Early Access Review

What is Sorcerer King?

An expansion of the Elemental games?  No.  And this seems to be a lot of the problem that people posting negative reviews have.   SK is a different game set in the same universe.   If you play the game from that mindset, you will find a lot in SK to like.

There are enough similarities to the other Elemental games that you will get a nice, warm, notalgic glow from playing, but not so much that it feels like the same old game.

The game, while still strategic, moves at a much faster pace.  The Doomsday Counter is the bane of those who prefer to sit back and methodically build an empire.

The graphics style has changed.  Some will see this as an improvement, some won't.  Personally, I like the new style much better than the old.

Although you can rename any unit in your army, designing your own units is gone.

Basically, you unlock unit types which you can then build if you have the necessary resources. Apart from hero units ( of which there are much fewer ) , Individual units do level up and can be customized to certain extent, but not to the extent of the other Elemental games.

The best way to describe Sorcerer King is that it is a much more focused game than its Elemental brethren.  The point of the game is to stop the Sorcerer King - not to build a huge sprawling empire.  If you spread your empire too far and too fast, the Sorcerer King's minions show up on your doorstep to crush you.   Of course, if you spread too slow, they eventually show up and crush you anyway too.

So, should you buy Sorcerer King?

If you are looking for an expansion of the previous Elemental games, I would say no.

But if you are looking for a fun game in the Elemental universe, I would say, definitely.

As game balancing improves, the game can only get better and better.

I say to you, Go forth and stop the apocalypse !  End the Sorcerer King ! ""

Review Update 6-27-15, 74 hours
I am going to change my opinion of this game. I reopened a game after many month and updates to find out if anything has changed with this game. Suprisingly I am thinking more favorable about it now. There have been many tweaks to the game that have made this a more enjoyable experience. Although it still is not the sequal that I had hoped for I do find itt now a worth while game to sit down to. Hope it continues.

1st Impression 35hrs
First off I understand Sorcerer King (SK)  is now out of Beta and into Early Access with improvements possibly still to come. Somehow at this stage I doubt there is a lot that would be changed.

Second I played Elemental a bit and thought the concept amazing, a civ type game in a fantasy world setting. Loved it. Though there were many bugs and some bad excecution,  I was excited to see the coming of Fallen Enchantress (FE). Great improvement from one game to the next though still some noticeable bugs  and some concepts not fully materialized to make it the next great game for me.

Present. A game concept with the idea to continue from game end of the last, you the loser, the same world elements and same unique artwork.  After playing this game roughly 30 hours on a couple play throughs I find it having a lot of potential but lacking. To me, and just my opinion, this game lacks on a great many levels and some serious backwards steps to a concept I hoped would get better.

Pros:
* Overall look: Art work is much better than previous games. Characters have more definition and diversity in appearance. Animations and actions are pretty cool. Beautiful work here.
* Game flow: Turns move much quicker and the game moves on at a nice pace.
* The enemy js continually sending out attackers/ armies, that actually give a decent amount of XP instead of (1) per unit. (This was the case in FE a concept that drove me nuts when the monster lairs ran dry).
* A crafting system to add / remove items as needed to all units. Not sure if I like this yet vs pooling resources for unit production. Atm will list as pro.
* Sovereigns: I like the overlooking ruler with a skill tree of their own to aid the minor faction as it grows to a kingdom able stand agaist the SK..
* Magic: Having limited spells in combat is a nice touch. Pick what you need to win or aid you vs unlimited access in FE
* Champions: Again less is better. One or two to make it count is better. Take your champion were its needed instead of one for every army. Only grip is how quickly the skill tree maxes out. Some skills seem kind of lame, some  are supper cool really only giving me the desire to use on or two since the others are clearly less effective.
* Logistics: Great concept. Army count based off support of city and buildings built. Just takes the burden out of the players hands to micro manage finances. Now just field your armies and enjoy the game with the logistical count available.

Whatevers:
* Single city tiles (SK) vs build on towns (FE). Personally I liked the build on town in (FE). This was a very unique design that mad it feel as if my towns were growing in size and scope. I also like the simple version of the single tile system. It is very clean and still changes as it grows taking much less space so max level cities are not hording the map realestate, limiting room to march armies or having the AI go for one more town that won't grow right next to you.
* Army size: (FE) had what I thought to be pretty cool units size. Individual, squad, company, etc. Ths idea was completly thtown out in (SK). I personally like the growing army size in (FE) but seeing as units start with 1x3 size its sort of a wash aside from the odd 1x1 units you start with or aquire through the course of gameplay.
Resources: Logistical build vs stockpiling resource. Both seem to have useable functions to the game and add their own flair. Set amount to use (SK) vs limited to abundance through gameplay (FE)

Cons:
* Although the overall look and feel has been enhanced, the overall game just seems to be lacking some functional depth. The concept of the game is epic. An all powerful sorcerer king has begun his actions to end the world as we know it and yet it just doesn't feel translated into the game as it progresses.
* Battles: For me they lasted roughly half a turn, maybe one with me. I usually never feared the death to my mundane groupe of soldiers. There is never a real sense of a armies clashing taking place. Since battle is fairly weak there is no real need for strategy in the much more defined battlemap and its choke points, no need for diverse units and no need for the plethera of now worthless spells to cast or special moves. Why cant some depth be given to city/ castel fights. Walls, ramparts, towers? Something to make it feel more grand. No this is not Total War but, it is still a castle.
* Magic: Lots of spells, most seem useless or a repeat in a different form. Without a variety of foes, weaknesses and strengths, there is not much need for a variety of spells.
Tactical: Since battles end so quickly why the need for lots of options? You wont get to use any. Though (FE) battles lasted a little longer the same problem persists. There isn't much stategic value using them when other skills can be employeed over and over at the same result or faster. Casting the spell just takes a move away from my unit to give a crap bonus for or against when I can just walk up and hack it.
Strategic: Lots of them that just seem unbalanced, wasted time, or a rarely seen or valued opportunity to cast aside from city enchantments. Limited terraforming spells in this rendition seem pretty usless or bugged at the moment.
* Crafted Items: Great idea, aweful excection. I can make cool items to give my hard working soldiers and champs!? Here guys try this piece of crap I made for you that really doesn't change a thing! Who cares about a ring that give a mighty +1 hp. Are you kidding me? Outside the armors, most craftable items are a waste of time and resources that wont effect much unless enchanted which really only has about 7 options at this time. The rest of your options come from loot infused as enchantment which takes up far too much space instead of being stacked for a quick easy look at what you have relative to what it does. We dont need 4 items scattered across 3 pages to know we have a lot of clouded rubies. Important resources for the nice gear are just too infrequent to make me care about the process. Waapons should progress allowing a nice order and time frame from low to high instead of being able to make two (worst and best) skipping all in between by the time I get said resources.
* Cities: Appear to have been turned into very basic linear choice without much variety. Since your choices of where to build have relatively taken away there aren't bonus structuers, such as being next to a river like a dock (FE). Could we also try the previously mention here too? Units should stack as army inside the city for one option, not each. Not a nig deal but its just the missed attention to detail that nags at me and being tired of looking at my army of administrators..
*Outposts seem more for decoration and tower defense than an integral part of the game outside of grabing a resource. I loved them in (FE) for atk/def/ move bonuses and population boosting. Felt more like expanding my kingdom instead of putting up a sign.
* Though AI turns move faster the overall game seems to as well, as if some of the meat has been taken out to give you a very fast unengagging flat experiance. The graphics and art may have improved along with a few new or improved concepts but sadly thats about where it ends.

In closing I will say I just expected and hoped for more. At this time if it stays as it is and at the current cost, so should you. Wait for a special. If you want something quick and easy with little fulfilment or attachment, this is for you.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. _Elemental: War of Magic_ was a great idea, implemented poorly; this is a brilliant idea, implemented very nicely indeed (although it does make my computer, which can run _Skyrim_ all day without trouble, run surprisingly hot). This isn't quite the world's first successful strategy-RPG -- the first game which is both uncompromisingly a strategy game and uncompromisingly a Japanese-style RPG -- but it shows what that game would look like; among the secrets are sharply circumscribing the range of available possibilities, and creating a scenario which can play out in broad strokes that the game can recognize, even when the details are wildly different from game to game.

_Sorceror King_ is also a worthy successor to _Master of Magic_, probably the first game that can really call itself _Master of Magic 2_. It even includes the part where High Men Paladins are a strategy in themselves :) -- and more seriously, it has the exact same feel, but more modern, more fully implemented and fleshed-out. Your character is more sympathetic, too, unless you go out of your way to choose the evil vassal.

As a game itself, it's superb -- although also horribly addictive in the classic just-one-more-turn manner of spacefaring 4Xes. I can recommend this too strongly, if there's anything else you want to do with your life; but still, it's really, really good.

Atmospherically, the game is odd. The Sorceror King is plotting to destroy all life and absorb the whole world into himself; he's a savage brute, a torturer and slave-driver; but he's just so _gullible_. And _helpful_. If he went to Atlantic City he'd get scammed in shell games. Even though he's an absolute moral monster, I almost feel _guilty_ about stabbing him in the back.

(By the way, there's a spell which the Sorceror-King is unimaginably weak against. Make modest use of it, and you can cheese the game; you can win well before what was supposed to be the halfway point. The miracle spell in question? Raise Terrain.

(Create Road is pretty game-busting, too.)

Once I had three archers on my team, only two were firing automatically and this actually cost them their next turn somehow.  The final skill to watch out for is the sovereign skill belonging to the general sovereign.  It says that it will allow all of your troops to attack first, but what it doesn;t say is that the leader of the army (the army receives its name from the leader) uses this sovereign skill costing your leader their turn.  Along with that issue, is that moves like Rush and Scurry do not work during this first attack phase.  Don't get me wrong, I am probably going to get all of the achievements and am enjoying what I experience, I just feel the need to warn future players.  I also believe I could refind this game months or years from now and still enjoy playing it.
